Speaker: Mr WENTWORTH
Title: AUSTRALIAN DEFENCE FORCES
text: Mr Speaker, I give notice that at the next day of sitting I shall move: I. That under the provisions of standing order 316, this House orders that there be laid before it the following papers which were compUed with the advice of some of the most distinguished experts in the field, and which were presented to the Australian Defence Conference recendy held in assembled. The humble Sydney: (a) A paper entitled Strategic Assessment of Australia's Security, presented by Colonel Eric Smith DSO, lately BattaUon Commander in Vietnam and Director of Training for the Army; (b) A paper entitled What Measures are Necessary in the Next Decade for Australia to Acquire a Self-reliant Defence Capability?, presented by Colonel R. C. Garland who retired from the Australian Regular Army last year and who has achieved an international reputation as a specialist egy; (c) A paper entitled In What Way Should Current Defence Allocations be Varied?, presented by ViceAdmiral Sir Alan MCNicoU, OE, CB, CBE, GM, formerly Chief of the Australian Naval Staff. 2. That in the opinion of this House this order should be made prompdy, so that the materia! in these papers may bc placed before honourable members when the defence estimates are being debated. NA NA

Speaker: Mr JARMAN
Title: CIRCULATION OF LABOR PARTY
text: I ask the Minister for Science and Consumer Affairs: Is it correct that officers the Bureau of Meteorology in Melbourne repolicy. cendy received unsolicited copies of the Austhat tralian Labor Party Platform, Constitution Rules, sent to them in departmental envelopes using the internal delivery system of Bureau? Is it also correct, as has been said to that a similar distribution was made in the Dethe partment of Labor and Immigration when the honourable gentleman was Minister for that Desion partment? Will the Minister institute inquiries ascertain at whose direction these actions took place and give instructions to officers of his partment that such dissemination of Party pohticordingly. cal propaganda, using government facilities, why. does not recur?

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Title: CIRCULATION OF LABOR PARTY
text: Yes , it is true that I arranged for copies of the Platform to be sent to senior officers in the Department of Labor and Immigration. I did it for the purpose of enabling them to understand the Government's pohcy. When the Liberal Party is able to state its pohcy in a printed platform and if it ever gets into government again I suggest that this very convenient way for it to let officers know its policy. I did not know that the Bureau of Meteorology had received its copies. I am glad that it has. I gave instructions to the Secretary of my Department to see that the Bureau got copies and to ensure that every agency within my try received a copy of the Government's policy.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: CIRCULATION OF LABOR PARTY
text: They are coming in out of the wet.

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Title: CIRCULATION OF LABOR PARTY
text: They are coming in out of the wet, as the Prime Minister says. This the most convenient way in which the Governin ment can tell the PubUc Service what its pohcy The Labor Party's pohcy is stated clearly in its on tactics and stratPlatform. Let me mention something against myself. On one occasion I found myselfreturninga letter to the central office to be rephrased because I did not like the way it was worded. I was simply told by the Department that the letter complied strictly with another section of the Platform which I had instructed officers to carry out. I think it is very sensible for a Party when in government to tell the Pubhc Service what it stands for and to give its pohcy to the Public Service in black and white so that while that Party is in office the Pubhc Service, whether it agrees with the pohcy or not, has a duty to carry it out. By giving copies of the Platform to every senior officer in the Department we put those officers in PLATFORM a position of knowing precisely where they stand while a particular Party is in office, although the of officer may not necessarily be in favour of the I intend to keep on doing this. In fact now the question has been raised-the honourand able member refers only to the Bureau of Meteorology- I will check to see whether the that Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial me, Research Organisation has its copy and whether Institute of Marine Science has its copy. I will see whether Mr Norgard of the Metric ConverBoard has his copy. I will find out whether to the Austrahan Science and Technology Council has its copy. I will have a look at all my colonies Deto find out whether they have been supplied acIf they have not I will want to know NA

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: DISTINGUISHED VISITORS
text: I have to inform the House that we have present in the gallery this morning a ParUamentary Delegation from Canada led by the honourable Louise Marguerite Renaude Lapointe, Speaker of the Canadian Senate. On behalf of the House I extend a very warm welwould be a come to the delegation. NA NA NA

Speaker: Mr KEITH JOHNSON
Title: DEVELOPMENT SCHEME
text: Is the Prime Minisminister aware of any suggestion that funds for Medibank or the Regional Employment Development scheme should be withheld?

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: DEVELOPMENT SCHEME
text: The only suggestions of this character that I have heard in the last few days were those made by the Leader of the Oppois sition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition the course of some reference they made yesteris. day to some purloined draft letter. The weekend before last they disciplined the honourable member for Hotham who is the Opposition spokesman who deals with Medibank. Now they are apparently conniving for Medibank funds to be withheld and are promoting with their colleagues in the Senate the idea that they reject any funds which might be required for Medibank above those already appropriated by the Parliament. Some of their State colleaguesPremiers-hav e now moved to adopt the benefits of the scheme. Some persons in the gallery might wonder why in the Australian federation we are still straggling to implement free hospitalisation which has been available in our sister federation of Canada for many years. I would like to conceal our national shame pointing out that earUer when there was a Labor Federal government- a National Democratic Party Government as they would know it-in the late 1940s, it was able to secure free hospitaliswas ation throughout Australia. When a Liberal government- a Conservative government as they would know it-cam e to office in the early 1950s, out. it scuttled the scheme. We are now catching up with what Labor provincial governmentsfirstin Saskatchewan achieved 15 years or so ago and what governments of aU pohtical persuasions Canada, federally and provincially, have been able to secure for their citizens now for some years past. The Australian Government, not my without difficulty, has been able to get the necessary legislation through the national ment. There is only one provincial Premier waiting to co-operate, the Liberal Premier New South Wales-ou r Ontario. Having chopped up Chipp last week they have decided to lull Medibank in a slightly more subtle way. But even the newspapers have it. I am told that the Leader of the Opposition made a visit-by no means the first-to the headquarters of the Sydney Momingsomewhat Herald last night-off Broadway. But if honourdocument able members look at the editorials this morning, they will see that this off Broadway appearance was a flop. NA NA

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: LEGISLATION
text: I ask the Prime Minister whether he is now prepared to answer questions which he was not prepared or able answer yesterday. Will there be a need for supdocuments plementary Supply legislation to meet the to Government's commitments for Medibank, the Regional Employment Development schemes or any other aspects of Supply?

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: LEGISLATION
text: I would think not. Nevertheless, this is a matter which it would be proper to ask of the Treasurer who is the Minister responsible for Medibank or of the Minister representing the Minister who is responsible for should the Regional Employment Development scheme. The honourable gentleman still is not very dexterous in deaUng with purloined documents. He asked me about this yesterday, I admit, and on this occasion he was backed up by his Deputy whose loyalty to successive leaders is a matter of notoriety in his organisation. They asked questions yesterday of me about a letter and quite frankly I could not see what they were driving at-wha t they were trying to identify. Later on the honourable gentleman was good by enough to table the document. It was undated. That does not often happen in letters addressed to me. It was unsigned, which happens more rarely in letters addressed to me. Furthermore, it on a size of paper which the Treasury, in its multitudinous correspondence with me, has never used. There was a Une or a few lines left Mr Jacobi-In pink?

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: LEGISLATION
text: No, this was a photostat in copy. It had about 9 or 10 paragraphs. It was dealing with a matter which was my responsibiUty and which naturaUy, in accordance with usual habit, I settled quite promptly five or six weeks ago. There was a passingreferencein ParUaone paragraph to the Regional Employment stUl Development scheme and to Medibank commitof ments about which the Treasurer said he was writing to the Ministers concerned. The Opposition should have learned by now the folly of using purloined documents without obtaining copies of the prospective correspondence menwill not tioned in such documents. I can see that the Leader of the Opposition was slow in getting on to this issue. This was quoted in the Sun News Pictorial in Melbourne at the begmning of last month and in one of the partners in that newspaper chain, the Brisbane Courier-Mail, at the beginning of last month-fiv e or six weeks ago. The Leader of the Opposition apparently heard about it this week.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Title: LEGISLATION
text: That is quick for him.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: LEGISLATION
text: No, up until now he has left to aU the procurement and selling of purloined to his deputy. But now he has decided take it on himself. He is to be the gentleman fence. He could not sell it to one of the other newspaper monopoUes yesterday, as I have just recounted. The Sydney Morning Herald thought it might be good news but those who ran the policy, those who back or bucket pohticians editorially, said 'it was not the right time'. The Sydney Morning Herald, at this stage, will not yet endorse the use of stolen documents. NA

Speaker: Mr COATES
Title: GOVERNMENT EXPENDITURE
text: Can the Treasurer say whether the Government gave careful considerauon to ways of achieving a reduction in pubhc spending during the preparation of the Budget? Is he able to say whether there are additional measures through which an extra $ 1,000m in savings could have been achieved?

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: GOVERNMENT EXPENDITURE
text: No. We do not beheve there is room for another $ 1,000m in savings. In fact, with the best determination in the world the position still falls short in its sums by some $500m in accounting for the cuts which it poses to bring about if it were to be a governincreased ment. The facts are tiiat the sort of cuts which it proposing if apphed would lead to extensive retrenchments. People such as school teachers, community health workers, social workers, industry fears? draftsmen, engineers, architects, building workers, road workers and a host of other people would be affected by such substantial cuts. There is no possibihty of the private sector being able to absorb such extensive retrenchgross ments immediately or even in a reasonably short period. So what the Opposition is proposing in Budget strategy, although its budget fits within the general money parameters that we had outlined, in detail is more contractionary. Not only would it lead to substantial retrenchments in the pubhc sector of the economy which could not, I repeat, be absorbed in the private sector, but a significant section of the corporate would also be adversely affected because the deniable fact is that the level of activity in private sector of the economy at the present has been sustained very much by the level of expenditure from the pubhc sector. The sudden withdrawal of that expenditure by a Liberalcertain National Country Party government would have serious consequences for the private sector. In short the Opposition has not done its sums. The sort of detailed program that does not match up to the proposals which it has put forward as its objectives to the Parliament. What we would hke the Opposition to do, as we have already forced it to come clean in more detail on its program, is to indicate exactly that other $500m of cuts which are unaccounted for yet would fall. Would it be school teachers? Would it be the pre-school program? Would it be the end of the community health centre program? Would it be the end of the school dental therapy program whereby every primary school child in Austraha would have free dental treatment by the early 1980s? Would it be the end of community welfare services that have been developed? Would it be a cutback in the road development program which we have been generously funding? Would it be a severe excision of expenditure in welfare housing? Let the Opposition come clean and state exactly what its Budget proposals are in detail. NA

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Title: COAL EXPORT LEVY
text: I ask the Minister for Minerals and Energy: Is the $6 tax per ton on coking coal and $2 per ton on steaming coal particularly Opsevere on coal mines in New South Wales? Is the Minister aware of the narrow margins within prowhich mine proprietors are working even with export prices? Will he undertake to is review the tax and report the impUcations to this House and his colleagues with a view to its cancellation if the effects are as disastrous as the

Speaker: Mr CONNOR
Title: COAL EXPORT LEVY
text: The effects of the proposed tax will not be disastrous. In fact they will be beneficial to Commonwealth consolidated revenue. I have already informed the House that profits for the forthcoming year on export coal wiU be of the order of $544m, of which only its a net amount of $69m will be absorbed by the new export tax after due aUowance is made for company tax. The tax wiU represent about oneeighth of their total profit- a not unreasonable amount. The underground coal mines in New South Wales wiU be in a rather less advantageous position as a result of this tax than their sector counterparts in Queensland which have the unadvantage of low cost open cut production. the Nevertheless, they are doing remarkably well time and were doing remarkably well before we went to Japan at the end of June to renegotiate the pricing structure. There could be problems for smaU steaming coal producers. I have already met representatives of four of those companies and have received details of their cost structure and contracts and they are currently it has outlined being examined. NA

Speaker: Mr DUTHIE
Title: BEEF INDUSTRY
text: I ask the Minister for Overseas Trade whether he has seen a report which sugwhere gests that the beef export industry may have passed through its worse stage. Is the Minister able to provide the House with any more information on the present position of beef exporters?

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: BEEF INDUSTRY
text: This is my maiden question as Minister for Overseas Trade. Everybody must be very happy with the administration of the Department of Overseas Trade. I hope that the beef industry has passed through the worse of its phases but it by no means yet faces a very pleasant prospect. It needs to be borne in mind that we have reached the stage in Australia where something like 60 per cent of the capacity of the beef industry is devoted to sales overseas. The principal markets in the past have been the United States of America, Japan, Europe and the United Kingdom. Due to economic recession all those countries have put restrictions upon the access of Australian beef to their markets. We have been able to negotiate a quota arrangement with the United States which, while not being as satisfactory as we would Uke, is certainly better than nothing. Recently, because some other countries that were participating in the quota arrangements were not able to fulfil their deliveries, we secured a further quota of 10 000 tonnes. More recently the Japanese market has begun to open up shghtly and there are prospects of it being better in the future. I am afraid that the European market for the time being is a very bleak prospect. However, it seems that some experts believe, and to some extent I support their view, that likelihood is that by 1976 there could again world shortage of beef. This is an unfortunate situation, but Australia cannot be expected to have the beef on hand just in case some other country runs short. We should endeavour as as possible to get forward orders, at least for parillegal ticular quantities, and we do work in that direcdisplaced tion. We recently opened up a market in Russia for 40 000 tonnes. Unfortunately, due to shipment ping and other problems, we were able to dehver only 35 000 tonnes. However, I assure the honourable gentleman that the Department of Overseas Trade, the Minister for Agriculture and I are taking all the steps we can to secure access and certainty of quantity. NA

Speaker: Mr LYNCH
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT
text: I ask the Treasurer When did he receive information that unemployment would rise to 400 000 in January? Was this development taken into consideration when forThere mulating the Budget strategy?

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT
text: If the honourable member cares to read within the next few weeks, if the time, the statements attached to the Budget documents, especiaUy statement No. 2, he will note that there is discussion about the future prospects of the work force and that it is our beUef that the Budget strategy provides for an improvement in the level of activity in the labour market. However it is also pomted out that there may well be some unevenness in the rate of recovery generally in the economy and in that section. What has been said there is consistent with the point that has just been raised. NA

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT FIGURES
text: Can the Minister representing the Minister for Labor and Immigration inform the House why the unemployment ngures compiled by the Department ofLabor and Immigration from its Commonwealth Employment Service records are substantially in excess of those produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics through its quarterly labour force survey? In view of the fact that the Bureau's unemployment ngures are compiled on an internationally accepted basis, what reUance can be placed on the CES figures as an accurate measure of unemployment in this country?

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT FIGURES
text: The former Minister for Labor and Immigration, the Hon. Clyde Cameron, explained on 19 May this year that the Commonwealth Employment Servicefiguresdo not purport to show the number of people actuthe aUy out of work. They show the number of perbe a sons who are registered for employment, and there is and can be a significant difference between the 2figures.There is no reason why a person who is employed cannot register in order to far seek another job. He breaks no law. It is no act for him to register in this way. People from one occupation may take a job in another industry. They may register for employin their old industry in the hope that a vacancy wiU occur and they will be able to return to their previous employment. Persons looking for a second job or part-time work may register. If those facts are known to the Commonwealth freer Employment Service, such people are not included in thefigures.However, frequently the facts are not disclosed. The staff limitations imposed on the Commonwealth Employment Service prevent a thorough and complete clearing out of persons who obtain employment and who are not in receipt of unemployment benefit. are, in fact, some long delays occurring at the moment in some instances between the time people who are registered for employment obtain employment and thetimethey notify the he has Commonwealth Employment Service, and some of those people are shown in the Commonwealth Employment Servicefigures.It therefore follows that people who are no longer available for employment can be and in some cases are still registered under the Commonwealth Employment Service figure. On the other hand it has to be said that some persons looking for work may not be registered under the Commonwealth Employment Service figures. It is, however, beheved by the Department of Labor and Immigration that the introduction of schemes, such as the National Employment and Training scheme and the Regional Employment Development scheme and the general manpower planning schemes which were developed by the previous Minister, have encouraged persons to use the Commonwealth Employment Service more regularly for the purpose of obtaining employment. The procedures for compiling labour statistics in Austraha, to the undying shame of the Opposition when in Government, are simply not adequate for current purposes. They are quite inadequate when compared with those of almost all industrially developed countries overseas. This Government has introduced a Bureau of Labour Economics, and that body will certainly improve the situation once it gets started. As explained last May, the Commonwealth Employment Servicefiguresare at variance with the Bureau of Statistics survey. In May, which is the last month for which figures are available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the number shown out of work as a result of the scientific survey undertaken was 192 000 persons. The Commonwealth Employment Servicefigurewas 248 000 for persons available for employment. That is a difference of some 56 000 persons. The Department of Labor and Immigration recognises the deficiency in the Commonwealth Employment Service figures, and that Department has strongly urged the Australian Bureau of Statistics to undertake its employment survey on a monthly basis rather than on the present irregular basis. Without dirninishing in any way the seriousness of the unemployment situation, it must be said that the Commonwealth Employment Servicefigurescan and in fact do overstate somewhat the position of unemployed persons. The lack of really sophisticated information opens the way for irresponsible speculation, estimation and mischievous guesswork on what unemploymentfiguresare or are likely to be. NA

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT
text: My question is making, addressed to the Treasurer. The Treasurer has assured the House that the unemployment rise expected in January was taken into consideration in the Budget strategy. Does he acknowledge that the Budget strategy would have been planned in July? If so, does he agree that there is a wide discrepancy between his answer and the statement made in the House yesterday by the Minister representing the Minister for Labor and Immigration who said that the Government learned only iast week that the unemployment figure would reach 400 000 in January? Can he explain the difference?

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT
text: The first point to which we should address ourselves is the similarity between the general Budget parameters of the Opposition and the Government. Accordingly, on that basis alone, the Opposition has excluded much ground for criticism of the Government.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT
text: Answe r the question.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT
text: I will answer it, but I will take the opportunity in doing so to score a few points. While I was away I noted the comments of the Minister for Overseas Trade and Acting Treasurer in the course of a debate in this House in which he advised the Opposition, post effect, of the undesirability of an Opposition detailing what its Budget would be. I think the Opposition will learn that lesson the hard way. It has practically excluded the grounds for genuine disagreement between the Opposition and this Government because it has adopted the general parameters which were outlined in our Budget. There is an area of some difference, and that is in the detail. If the Opposition is worried about the level of unemployment I ask it to reflect on the level of unemployment which its Budget as detailed would bring about. Who is going to feel the harsh axe of unemployment and severe retrenchment as a result of the substantial cut in the public sector which the Opposition proposes of about $ 1,000m, $500m of which is undefined and undeclared? When can we have the details ofthose proposals?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT
text: I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. Not one word that the Treasurer has said so far has any relevance to the question. The question was about the Government's own predictions from its own department that unemployment under its policies will reach 400 000.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT
text: Order! The honourable gentleman has made his point. I suggest that the Minister deal with the actual subject matter of the question.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: UNEMPLOYMENT
text: To continue the point I was the Opposition has left itself very little room for criticism of the Government's budgetary management. To the extent that in detail the Opposition's Budget represents contractive measures it would be more severe on the economy, on the corporate sector and on the work force. I rernind honourable members of the following comment at page 21 of Statement No. 2 attached to the Budget: Product growth of this order would probably be associated with an increase in employment of about cent in 1975-76 and a sizable recovery in productivity. I point out that that is an average rate of increase in employment On a June 1976 basis as against a June 1975 basis it will represent an increase, conservatively stated, of about 2 per cent. We hope that it may be even better than that. The comment continues: Given the likely growth in the labour force, the picture for unemployment consistent with these developments slow decline from the present high levels. However, uncertainties involved in the overall picture are such possibility of some unevenness in trend cannot be Of course, we anticipate that there will be a State higher level of unemployment due to seasonal Australia factors in the period from January That has always been so. We do not expect the covered that there hospital inputs from the Budget, or indeed any inputs ership of the Opposition-honourabl which a government may undertake at this point, might remember that that happened to have much effect before the early New Year. although with the rapid succession of changes Accordingly I suggest that the Leader of the Opposition and his economic adviser, his Deputy leadership Leader-the survivalist who is an economic organisation specialist in search of an understanding of simple not economic principles-ough t to go back to their then-an advisers and try to understand the sort of advice snap election, that they have been receiving. NA

Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Title: ALLEGED THEFT OF LETTER
text: Has the attention Treasurer been drawn to reports of the theft of a letter which was drafted for his considerauon by ister the Treasury? Can he give the House any inforall relevant mation about this letter or the thief?

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN

Speaker: Mr LUSHER
Title: MEDIBANK
text: In view of the importance of the Medibank estimates to the overall Budget deficit, will the Treasurer inform the House what the cost of the hospital part of the Medibank scheme is estimated to be in New South Wales this year and what it is estimated to be in a full year, this provision not having been included in the Budget as the agreement was not signed? Does the Treasurer agree with his colleague, the Deputy Prime Minister, that the costs of Medibank in Australia could reasonably be expected to rise to approximately the Canadian figure of $300 a head per annum, involving the Australian Government in outlays of about $4 billion in a fuU year?

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: MEDIBANK
text: I apologise for the embarrasstrahan ment of the Parliament caused by such a comSweden ment in the presence of the visiting Canadian members of Parhament who are present in the gaUery.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: MEDIBANK
text: Hear, Hear!

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: MEDIBANK
text: The fact is that Canadians and enjoy a far better system of health services than is enjoyed in this country. The Canadian Government spends about the same proportion of gross domestic product on health services does the United States of America. Yet, Canada covers everyone in that country for medical hospital care while in the United States it is matter of notorious concern that such a large proportion of the public is totaUy outside equate cover for these sorts of services. The rate of cost of health services in Canada has certainly escalated rather rapidly in recent years. This cost has escalated rather rapidly in cent years in all advanced economies. It has escalated at a far faster rate in the United States than in Canada. If we can achieve the standards which have been achieved in Canada in the qualis ity of health care and in the containment of medical and hospital costs, it will be a far superior achievement to the standards we had to bear with under the old discredited system of priit vate health insurance. There can be no doubt trade. that Medibank is here, and it is here to stay. The spokesman for the Opposition on health and pohcy welfare services, Mr Chipp, has been roundly rebuked and disowned by the Leader of the Opway position for suggesting that Medibank would dismantled. The Opposition is now committed Medibank. I will ask the Minister for Social Security to give me the latestfigureson hospital services costs in New South Wales and I wiU post them to the honourable member. NA

Speaker: Mr WALLIS
Title: TRANSPORT OF MINERALS
text: Has the attention of the Minisout ter for Transport been drawn to reports Japanese steel mills have refused to employ 4 bulk carriers now on order by the Australian National Line in the transport of iron ore and coal between Australia and Japan? Are these reports correct? If so, what steps are being taken by the Minister to ensure that these ships are used in our foreign trade to bring about a higher percentage of trade carried in Australian owned and manned ships?

Speaker: Mr CHARLES JONES
Title: TRANSPORT OF MINERALS
text: In April 1974, following discussions which the then Chairman and the General Manager of the Australian National Line had with the steel nulls in Japan, the AusGovernment decided to place an order in and in West Germany for the construction of two 120 000 ton bulk ships and two 140 000 ton bulk ships for the carriage of iron ore or coal from Austraha to Japan. A clear understanding was arrived at that if we had the ships we would get the work. So we went ahead placed orders on that clear understanding. I think that what honourable members have to understand is that in 1973-74 about 65 million tons of iron ore and coal was transported from as Australia to Japan and that not one ton of those minerals was carried in Australian ships that and were permanently on that trade between a Australia and Japan. A small amount of the minerals was carried occasionally by ships which at adthetimewere being positioned in Japan for some particular reason. We think that what we are doing is fair and reasonable, particularly when honourable members reaUse that freight rates on recoal and iron ore carried between Australia and Japan are roughly half the rates that Japan pays for the transport of coal and iron ore from other parts of the world. So the Australia-Japan trade one of the cheapest transport areas for Japan. In any case, the 4 ships to which I have referred would carry only about 7 per cent of Australia's total exports of coal and iron ore to Japan. I think is not unreasonable that we should get into this The Australia Government is committed to a of ensuring that 40 per cent of our exports are carried in Australian bottoms, and that is the in which we are working on this question. At be the moment there is a problem because of a to downturn in freight brought about by the world economic situation that exists today. Tankers of total capacity of thousands and thousands of tons aretiedup at present. The same thing can be said about bulk ships. The whole system of freight is under strong pressure because of the amount of tonnage that is being tied up throughthe world. There will be continuing disthat cussions between Australia and Japan NA NA

Speaker: Mr KEOGH
Title: WAGE INDEXATION
text: I direct my question to the Minister for Housing and Construction in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister Labor and Immigration. I ask: Is there strong support in the community for the concept of wage indexation? Does the Government adhere to the beUef that wage indexation will assist stabilising inflationary pressures? Can he say whether there has been any concerted opposition to the Government's pohcy on wage indexation from any particular source or from any combiarticle nation of interests?

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN
Title: WAGE INDEXATION
text: There is now widespread would support for wage indexation since the ConciUof ation and Arbitration Commission adopted it as a result of the initiative of this Government and said: the trade union movement. There is, of course, some opposition. Some employers now support the proposal for wage indexation. AU State indexation. governments, iixespective of poltiical flavour, support wage indexation. Some employers- a diminishing number-ar e opposed to wage indexation. The Opposition has made it clear from the outset that its members are the uncompromisingly opposed to wage indexation. Wage mdexation certainly stabilises costs in it removes the need for employee groups to claim in expectation of higher cost escalation. The strong opposition by the Liberal and National Country Parties has to be read with interest order to be beUeved. On 10 December 1974 the Leader of the National Country Party said that wage mdexation should not be countenanced for Australia. He said that indexation would tend to stimulate inflation rather than slow it down, contrary to most sensible economic advice. He said it would add to the destruction of initiative and enterprise, but he also found it necessary to advocate at the same time the indexation of interest rates- a remarkable proposition-in to ensure that interest rates kept rising in accordance with the consumer price index. He saw indexation as part of a plot to achieve a subtle revolution in Australia- a remarkable assertion. On 14 July the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that he ruled out any chance that the a Opposition would support wage indexation. He said that the Government's pohcy was completely unacceptable to the Liberal and National Parties. Its introduction would be economic madness, was the way he put it. On 16 January the Leader of the National Country are Party, in the Melbourne Age, said that Mr Lynch-Without guarantees. Why do you not teU the truth about it.

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN
Title: WAGE INDEXATION
text: What I am saying is the absolute truth. On 16 January the Leader of the for National Countiy Party in an article in the Melbourne Age said that wage indexation would be another insidious method by which the most productive people would be penaUsed and further in discouraged from working harder, working overtime or advancing themselves to higher positions. On 20 January the learned scribe, Mr Malcolm Fraser M.P., as he then was, said in an in the Sydney Morning Herald that the Liberal-Countr y Party had strong opposition to wage indexation because it beUeved that it be just one further ratchet in the process wage escalation. On 21 January in an article in the Adelaide Advertiser the learned scribe also I am certain Australia cannot take the risk of introducing Mr Snedden on 27 January said that indexation would further aggravate the inflationary impact of wage claims, displaying an appalling ignorance of the situation. In his Budget speech Leader of the Opposition said that wage determination procedures chosen by the Concilithat ation and Arbitration Commission must be supported. He attempts to mislead people. What he means is that if, in spite of his opposition, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission grants in wage indexation, he will say that everybody must support it. I add that in the Liberal National Country Party manifesto for industrial confrontation-calle d their industrial relations policy-the y are clear in their exclusion of wage indexation as a method of wage fixation. They listen to far too many experts-expert s who are hardly qualified on the subject. I remind them of the advice given by a former Prime Minister of  ways for a poUtician to ruin a career-chasin g women, gambling and trusting experts. He said that the first was the most pleasant, the second the quickest and the third, trusting experts, was the surest.

Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation. It arises from the Grievance Day debate last Thursday. As reported at page 1025 of the House ofRepresentaof tives Hansard of 4 September 1975,1 named a the medical practice and the doctors in it. In the deyear bate I said that the circular which they had sent around prior to the introduction of Medibank stated that they intended to do certain things which I claimed were Ulegal. I now understand that what they meant to say was not that they bulk bill and then charge an extra fee for I home and hospital visits but that they would in on respect of home and hospital visits be acting as for the patients to Medibank. That is, they limwould be getting the patients to fill in the at this Medibank claim forms as distinct from the in assignment of benefit form and would be charging the patients the remainder of the normal fee for those services. This practice, of course, is not Ulegal. But I do understand that these doctors are in fact bulk billing for ah services that they are rendering. I apologise to them for any embarrassment or inconvenience that my inaccurate representation of their activities has caused

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: MINERALS AND ENERGY POLICIES
text: I move: That this House condemns the failure of the Government to provide a white paper on minerals and energy policies while destroying confidence in the industries' future. The subject which I want to raise is one which is not new to this House. Far from it. Last year the examiners of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development reporting on science poUcy in Australia criticised the Government in the strongest possible terms for its failure to spell out a satisfactory energy poUcy. In their report they said: With regard to its energy resources Australia has a privileged posiuon in the world. The country possesses important domesdc resources in coal, petrol, gas and uranium which will probably protect it over a long period from the direct repercussions of the world energy crisis. The situation does not prevent Australia from having to define a coherent policy with respect to the most rational manner of using and exploiting these resources. At the present time, however, there is no energy policy at the nadonal level. While no energy policy applicable to Australia as a whole, research in the field of energy on the contrary is placed under Commonwealth responsibility within 3 bodies-the National Coal Research Committee, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, and for petroleum research the Bureau of Mineral Resources. It is also under Commonwealth initiadve that important work on the use of solar energy has been developed placing Australia at the vanguard of world research in this field. In the period since the report was made pubhc nothing has happened to alter the situation. I challenge the Minister for Minerals and Energy (Mr Connor) who will be speaking in this bate, to indicate if that is not correct. The rnining and oil exploration industries are than ever. Who would wonder why? If one looks at the record, the same appalling facts are revealed. When we look at the rruning industry throughout the whole of Austraha we see stagBlaxland nation, uncertainty and above all the devastating sense of insecurity. No major mining projects have been developed in the last Vh years, and this is the subject of another challenge I make you, Mr Minister. The production which is taking place today is from mines which were developed 3,5 or 8 years ago. We all know the causes of this stagnation in the mining industry. The overriding cause of the problems facing the rnining industry is the pohcies of the present Federal Governmonths ment, particularly the twisted ideological racial obsession and motivation of the Minister for Minerals and Energy. I know that this Minister deserves most of the blame for bringing the ing industry in Austraha to its present state confusion and crisis. But the Minister is a memtakes ber of a Government which has approved, even praised, all that he has done. It is that Governtomorrowment and the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) who must accept the ultimate responsibihty for present state of the mining industry. The Government's pohcies towards the minAustraUan ing industry are not simply the result of coning fusion and misunderstanding. The Governa ment's pohcy-not e this well-is one of dehberagainst ate sabotage of the rnining industry. I do not this tightly. I beheve that the present Governper ment is bent on socialising this country and to achieve this it must gain control of Austraha's greatest source of wealth-ou r huge rnineral resources. By bringing confusion and crisis rnining industry the Government can more easily gain control of these industries. Inflation is part of the strategy designed to drive the nuning panies out ofbusiness. If favourable world prices enable the companies to stay in front special taxes will be imposed as in the case of the tax on coal, which was a classical example. The mining industry should not forget that the Government's there is plans to borrow $4 bilhon overseas in back alleys were designed to put them out ofbusiness. In the field of mineral development we can be grateful that expansion was well under way before this Government came to office, otherwise the mining scene would resemble the devastation which marks the oil exploration scene in Australia today. The statistics of oil exploration tell the story of the effects of this Government's pohcies. Let me refer to them. In 1972 a total of 80 000 miles of seismic line testing was carried out; in 1973 this figure dropped-no t to any significant deextent, of course-to 8500 miles! In 1974 it dropped to 7000 miles and this year there has more confused been virtually none.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: MINERALS AND ENERGY POLICIES
text: Thos efiguresare wrong.

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: MINERALS AND ENERGY POLICIES
text: The honourable member for (Mr Keating) will have the opportunity to refute them. The last seismic vessel operating off the coast has now left Australian waters, so seismic testing has come to a complete standto still-o r has some new strategy been evolved, some new technique by which we do not need seismic vessels? A similar position exists with regard to wells drilled. In 1970 121 exploration weUs were driUed. In 1973 this fell to 69 wells drilled and to 55 in 1974, and in the first 6 of this .year only 14 weUs were drilled. The most disturbing aspect of Australian oil production is that we can now say with certainty that in 5 years time Australia will face its own oU mincrisis, and honourable members know what that of means. The reason we can say this is obvious; it at least 5 years to bring oU into production after it is discovered. If we found more oil I do not know who wouldfindit because nobody is looking for it very much-it the would be 5 years before it came on stream to Australian consumers. So we are looking at a minimum of 7 years before we can produce more oil. By 1982 Australia will be produconly approximately 100 milhon barrels of oil year. Let that figure be refuted. Measured an estimated consumption of 300 miUion say barrels a year this means that we wiU be only 30 cent self-sufficient in oil and that imports will cost over $2,000m a year-and that is at present prices. This is a frightening picture. to the This Government through its inaction and through its disastrous maladmiiustration will leave this country at the mercy of foreign oil procomducers by 1980. Our whole economy and our national security will be placed at risk because of the necessity to meet a huge biU for the import of foreign oil. The present disastrous state of affairs is the result of the dangerous poUcies of the Minister for Minerals and Energy designed to gain control of oil production in Australia. That is his absolute obsession. The Minister could obtain control of oil production in Australia only by forcing out those who were exploring for oil and held the most attractive leases. The withdrawal of the search subsidy, the ban on overseas investment and the statements by the Minister that there would be no increase in the price of new oil discovered in Australia were all part of a campaign to prevent further exploration. The Minister thought that he could then step in and take over the whole field himself. This dangerous design has cost Australia 3 years of oil exploration activities and the chance of discovering a major new field. The oil exploration industry has been forced out of Australia and will not return while this Government is in power. One of the most harmful aspects of Government's poUcy on ott exploration and properformance. duction is the oil pricing policy. In the next years Austraha's oil production will fall dramatically. By 1980 we wiU be only 40 per cent selfsufficient, given the continuation of the present expansion in consumption-and consumption ing will grow, as we aU know, and grow dramatiraise caUy. This means that we will have to import 170 miUion barrels of oil a year at a cost of nearly $ 1,500m, again at today's prices. These ngures are based on finding oil immediately but, as we aU know, we are not even looking for oil at the moment. The foUy of the oU pricing poUcy of the Government is that the development of fields with known reserves is being discouraged, not say anything about looking for more oil. There are hundreds of thousands of barrels of oil which we know exist in smaU fields such as Moonie, Barrow Island and Bass Strait, but the cost recovery is greater than the price such oil would fetch in Australia. The result is that we have import Middle East oil at $9 to be paid out of our very valuable overseas exchange. Honourable members should relate trol that to a deficit of $2,600m, or if they want work on a deficit of $700m in June they can ticipate that if taken to its extreme the deficit 1976 will be $8,000m. If that does not terrorise the people of Australia and make them want rid Australia of this Government I do not know what is needed. That is the worse proposition we could have-to use Australia's national earnings to import oil when we have oil in this country but when it is just not profitable to look for it. If, example, we paid 39 a barrel to Australian producers the Government would obtain revenue from the taxadon of profits and the costs involved in recovering that oil would be spent in Australia. If the Government cannot see the advantages of that then it is comprised of bigger dunderheads than I and the people of Australia have deemed them to be. It would also provide - obs for Australians and, my goodness, how badly are they needed. There can be no more short sighted policy than a general refusal to raise the price of the local product, which we have. Honourable members opposite wiU go out now and say, as they said about the leader of the National Country Party (Mr Anthony), that we want to raise the price of oil. That hoax is not working any longer because already under this Government people in inland parts of Australia are paying 90c a gallon for petrol, when previously they were paying something Uke 50c, and people in the cities are paying nearly that the amount. The people know the Government's Its track record is there. The Oppo5 sidon is presenting a logical proposition. It is inevitable that the price of oil willriseto Australian consumers. The Government is forcup the price of oil. There is no choice but to it because our own reserves are limited and the only alternative is to import expensive oil at $9 a barrel. The only issue involved is whether the rise occurs now or occurs graduaUy or occurs in 5 years time with a much greater impact. What has happened to the countries which have had to import oil at something Uke that price? What are they paying in Italy? In January they were payto ing $1.75 a gallon for petrol. In Great Britain they were paying $1.85 a gaUon. I do not know what they are paying now. A sudden jump in oil prices would lead to severe dislocation in indusof try and throughout the whole economy. The effect of an unrealistically low domestic price to would be to destroy any incentive to explore for a barrel which has oU in Australia. The Minister similarly attempted to gain conof Australia's uranium reserves by trying to to force the companies which held leases into bankanruptcy. He was temporarily outwitted over the in Ranger deposits when it became necessary for the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) to come up to with a plan to develop the reserves when the Japanese Prime Minister visited Australia last year. I suppose that was the beginning of the downfall of the Minister for Minerals and Energy because, as we know, he is almost a postscript now, or perhaps aU those who are guessing are wrong. However, the one spotlight was taken for off the Ranger agreement and the Minister had things in his hands again. The old pattern of frustration and calculated stonewalling surfaced again. This has extremely serious consequences for Austraha because there is a real possibility that we will miss the world market for uranium if we do not make contracts soon. I would like to turn to the pohcy of the alternaeral tive Government, an alternative which I hope will become a reahty in the near future for the sake of Australia and for the sake of every worker in Australia. The basic poUcy of a Liberal-National Country Party government would be to revitaUse the minerals industry and encourage the development of Austraha's rnineral resources. Two areas which come to mind immediately where development could be given the go-ahead are coal in the Bowen basin and uranium in the Northern Territory. It is about time someone dug a shovel in somewhere in those areas. Several projects are in an advanced stage of planning and only need approval for work to commence almost at once. An essential part of the Liberal-National Country Party program for recommencing the development of our rnineral resources would be to restore the State governments to their proper role in mineral plaruiing and development. Australian Minerals Council, consisting of the Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible is The for mining, would be revived, and promptly. The benefitthe Council has met only once since 1972, and then the direct on the initiative of the New South Wales MinisGovernmentparticipation ter for Mines. The most important step necessary to about renewed interest in nuning development Australia is to clear away some of the myths which surround the whole subject. If we are have a strong and healthy minerals industry which is able to contribute to Austraha's national development, we must face realities and not Uve in a dream world, throwing out deceitful and completely misleading concepts based on foreign ideologies. These have to be swept aside. Let me deal with one or two of these myths. The most important factor which we must reaUse is that to develop our mineral resources we need the assistance of others-thei r capital, knowledge and their markets. Overseas investsighted ment in Australia is the cornerstone of this counCountry try's economic development. Like all Austhe traUans-let me make this perfectly clear, as have made it clear from the day I offered myself for election in Kennedy- I want to see as Australian ownership of our natural resources possible. But we must recognise that Australia needs the experience of the overseas experts and that the benefits of the overseas investment far outweigh the disadvantages. Overseas investors provide jobs. Their investment leads to the creation of other industries, and they pay taxes. A Liberal-National Country Party government will adopt a case-by-case approach to overseas participation in the exploitation of Australia's minresources. We will aim at the highest practicable level of Australian ownership. Let me repeat that before honourable members opposite start screaming aboutMr Connor-Utah?

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: MINERALS AND ENERGY POLICIES
text: Yes, if you like, Utah. Let me repeat it before they start screaming about any of the overseas companies. We will aim at the highest practicable level of Australian ownership, but we will not bring all development to a halt as the Minister for Mineral and Energy has done because Australians are not wilUng to put up the capital required for a project. The Minister is the greatest dog in a manger that ever existed. He knows it well, his Government knows it well, and the Prime Minister knows it well. That is why he has to ease the Minister out. We do not adhere to the policy that if Australia cannot develop a resource no one else can either. The That is the myth of aU myths. second myth that we must get away from that Australian people can derive greater from the nation's mineral resources by of the Australian in mineral development. The Liberal and National Country Parties believe that bring the Commonwealth Government must play a in major role in encouraging the exploration for and development of Australia's minerals to resources, but the Government's role is one of creating the climate in which private enterprise will be able to carry out the task of finding and recovering the nation's mineral resources. The role of the Government is to define national policies and to draw up laws for the orderly development of Australia's natural resources. Another myth which surrounds the whole issue of mineral development is that we should conserve our mineral resources and leave them thenin the ground. Nothing could be more shortor disastrous. The Liberal and National Parties reject the notion that by leaving rninerals in the ground they will only appreciI ate in value. Apart from causing severe economic dislocation to our trading partners, this approach much also runs the risk of missing the market as altogether as the Minister knows he has done in regard to our uranium resources. I stress one point. It is my own particular baby, if I might put it that way. The group which has suffered most from the pohcies of the present Government is the small producers and the small explorers. The Liberal and National Country Parties will encourage and assist the exploration and nuning activities of small producers. Throughout Austraha there are numerous mineral deposits which do not attract the interest of major companies but which could be made profitable by the small operator or by a small group of miners. The Liberal and National Country Parties propose to estabhsh a small mine operators advisory panel to provide small niining operators, including those on the gem fields, with direct access to information and advice. I conclude by drawing the Minister's attention to an undertaking he gave in this House that he would provide me with a list of approvals which the Austrahan Industry Development Corporworth ation had given in relation to the apphcations small miners to gain assistance to get off the ground. He has never provided me with that. His secretary or whoever is responsible has sent me abusive. nebulous letters.

For thefirsttimewe are in a position where we are able to get full world parity. The price of export coal- I am speaking now in Australian dollars-wen t up. The price of Queensland hard coking coal went up from $11.50 a tonne to $37.50 a tonne-and that is supposed to be part of Labor's mismanagement. For the first time we can deal with the Japanese in terms of respect. They respect strength, they respect knowledge, they respect integrity and they have been getting it Despite the statements that have appeared in certain sections of the Australian Press, they got their answer last Tuesday from Mr Tanabe. Their relations with us are excellent and there is a clear understanding and empathy on both sides. The Country Party in particular would anything it could to disrupt the situation. The position in respect of oil exploration is Austrahan quite ludicrous. On the north west shelf of Western Austraha the requirements on renewal of the Western Austrahan Government are for 36 wells to be drilled over a period of 5 years. As I said in answer to a question in this House the other day, world parity is at least US$20 per it would not be enough for one drilling rig. In a few days' time there will be an announcement on the new indigenous oil pohcy, but I can say this much in advance, that 3 of the major oil producers of Austraha, together with Lewis Weekes, agree that the prospects for oil on the north shelf are severely limited. It is a gas prone area. agree with them in their suggestion that they should look further beyond the north west shelf and in the deeper waters. That matter is under consideration at the present time. As for the attempt by the honourable for Kennedy to suggest that the Government not conscious of the need to assist in the substanwere dard and small pockets of oil that are in certain reservoirs in Bass Strait, he will receive his answer on that too in the policy that will announced. In respect of his allegations that scores of millions of barrels of oil are available from Moonie, the hard fact is that there are 2.6 million barrels there that can be produced and no more. We will be giving assistance there. have had nothing but humbug from the State governments. National matters ought to be dealt with by the national Parhament. Only 14 milhon barrels of crude oil have been discovered. This individual here thinks that because you drill holes oil will pop out. Shell erals Exploration (Austraha) Pty Ltd, Esso Australia Ltd, the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd Lewis Weekes all say that it is a gas prone and the oil is beyond, for good and sound geofalsely logical reasons. On shore in Austraha there is none to be found, other than in thefigmentsof the imagination of the Opposition and of spokesmen as the honourable member for untappedKennedy. In respect of solar energy, Austraha already leads the world in the applications of low grade heat. Despite that there was an interjection. Thanks to the Labor Party Government we have delayed the development of uranium, and for very good reasons. When we took over there were contracts at give-away prices. The average price was US$6.50 per lb. At the present time lb. Mr Katter-Do you want credit for that?

Speaker: Mr CONNOR
Title: MINERALS AND ENERGY POLICIES
text: Yes. We had the foresight to do so. Of course, again, he would choose to humbug this House and attempt be to mislead. We have nothing of which to be afraid; we have everything of which to be proud. For the firsttimein Australia, there is a distinct portfoUo and there is a distinct government policy. It is a pohcy which is working and which will We provide for the future of Australia.
